title: Accountability & Encouragement
description: Discover how you help each other stay on track with goals.

questions.text: When it comes to accountability, I prefer you to...
choices: Check in regularly on my progress
Wait for me to bring it up
Gently remind me when I'm off track
Believe in me and let me handle it

therapeutic.rationale: Accountability preferences reflect autonomy needs and support styles. Regular check-ins provide structure; waiting respects initiative; gentle reminders offer guidance; belief provides space. Mismatched accountability can feel like nagging or abandonment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different accountability needs require explicit conversation. What feels supportive to one may feel intrusive to another. Ask what actually helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched accountability preferences make supporting each other's goals natural and welcomed.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What kind of accountability helps you most? Have you told your partner what you need?

questions.text: When you're working toward something important, I want to...
choices: Be your biggest cheerleader
Help with the practical steps
Give you space to focus
Celebrate your progress along the way

therapeutic.rationale: How we want to support reflects our giving style. Cheerleaders offer emotional fuel; helpers offer practical action; space-givers offer respect; celebrators offer acknowledgment. Knowing your partner's preference ensures your support lands.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Your natural support style may not match what your partner needs. Be flexible and ask what would actually help.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched support offerings and needs create smooth goal-pursuit dynamics.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you naturally want to support your partner? Is that what they actually need?

questions.text: Encouragement from you means the most when...
choices: I'm struggling and need to keep going
I've achieved something, big or small
I'm doubting myself
You notice effort even without results

therapeutic.rationale: When encouragement matters most reveals emotional needs. Struggle-needers want perseverance support; achievement-needers want acknowledgment; doubt-needers want reassurance; effort-noticers want to be seen. Timing matters as much as the words.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different timing needs mean watching for when your partner needs encouragement most. What helps in struggle may differ from what helps after success.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched timing preferences mean you'll naturally offer encouragement when it's most needed.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When does encouragement mean the most to you? Is your partner aware of this timing?

questions.text: When I fall short of a goal, I need you to...
choices: Help me understand what happened
Remind me it's okay and I can try again
Give me space to be disappointed
Focus on what I did accomplish

therapeutic.rationale: Setback response needs vary. Understanding-seekers want analysis; try-again types want hope; space-needers want room to process; accomplishment-focusers want perspective. Wrong response to setback can feel invalidating.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different setback needs require asking what would help, not assuming. The analysis-lover may frustrate the space-needer.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched setback responses create natural support when things don't go as planned.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need from your partner when you fall short of a goal?

questions.text: I believe the best way to help someone grow is to...
choices: Believe in them more than they believe in themselves
Be honest even when it's hard
Create safety for them to take risks
Walk alongside them on the journey

therapeutic.rationale: Growth philosophies shape how we support. Believers offer faith; honest ones offer truth; safety-creators offer security; walkers offer presence. All are valuable approaches to helping someone grow.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different growth philosophies can complement each other. The believer and the honest one together offer both faith and truth.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared growth philosophy creates aligned approach to supporting each other's development.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you believe you can best help your partner grow? Is that what they actually need?
